author: John Cross
title: Claudio Ranieri masterminded this league's greatest ever story - his sacking proves just how brutal football can be
text:
Claudio Ranieri 's last press conference Share this video Watch Next 
The decline from last season is easy to trace from the £30m sale of N’Golo Kante to Chelsea and with his departure went Leicester’s best player. 
But it runs deeper than that. Despite Ranieri’s heroics last season, it would be wrong to suggest he didn’t make mistakes trying to defend the title. 
The recruitment last summer was shockingly bad, £60m spent on Nampalys Mendy, Ahmed Musa and record signing Islam Slimani who cost £30m from Sporting Lisbon. Leicester's players lift the title aloft (Photo: Getty Images) Kante left Leicester for Chelsea (Photo: AFP/Getty) Ranieri speaks to Islam Slimani (Photo: Plumb Images) 
They have all struggled badly and Ranieri has made things worse by his constant tinkering with selections and tactics. 
That was in contrast to last year when he left behind his Tinkerman reputation to pick a settled starting XI which was perhaps the greatest strength of their title success. 
The players were all given huge contracts, as was Ranieri, and yet too many of the squad became complement and their hunger had gone with their £100,000-a-week pay cheques. 
It was clear that the players lost faith in him this season . He had effectively lost the dressing room, even inviting them to see the chairman if they were unhappy. And they clearly did. Ranieri speaks to his players (Photo: Getty) Claudio Ranieri speaks with Jamie Vardy and Demarai Gray (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Schmeichel shows his disappointment (Photo: REUTERS) 
Last season, Ranieri was the ultimate showman with his press conferences and dilly-ding, dilly-dong catchphrase. It took pressure off the players. 
This season, Ranieri has been rambling, his messages confusing and his facts wrong. The players got increasingly worried, to the point of Kasper Schmeichel having a row with Ranieri. 
The dissent was growing. Ranieri even upset the players by taking chicken burgers off the menu after games, once again his tinkering instincts coming through. 
It was noticeable that Leicester’s Thai owners watched from the edge of the pitch as the players warmed up in Sevilla on Wednesday which is something they do not usually do. Leicester City owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha in the stands (Photo: Reuters) 
Meanwhile, behind the scenes they knew what was coming. Ironically, Ranieri hugged Leicester’s goal scoring hero Vardy on the pitch after the game which perhaps was further proof that he did not see it coming. Or know the players had turned. 
Football is a brutal and unforgiving world and even the greatest ever title success does not buy you much credit. 
But to put it into perspective, Ranieri was voted FIFA world coach of the year on January 10. Now he is out of a job. poll loading Were Leicester City right to sack Claudio Ranieri? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
